text: My daughter died. It’ll be twenty-eight years this month. The thirtieth of this month, yeah.
keypoint: I remember my daughter's death anniversary

text: She died at Methodist Hospital. She had an operation for appendicitis. It was late Saturday afternoon when they operated, very late.
keypoint: She died after an appendicitis operation

text: Sunday morning, my oldest daughter, Victoria, went to the hospital to see how she was. She was still under ether. Back then, they used a lot of ether.
keypoint: My daughter was under ether post-surgery

text: There was a chair there. They were just starting to get people out of bed, you know. So, Victoria saw the chair, and she said to the nurse, “What’s this chair doing here?”
keypoint: They planned to get her out of bed too soon

text: The nurse said, “Well, we’ve got to get her out of bed.” She said, “What are you talking about? She’s still under ether.” “She’s too sick.” But the nurse said, “Well, that’s the doctor’s orders.”
keypoint: The nurse insisted on following doctor's orders

text: So, they went to get her out of bed, and she passed out, and they had to put her back in bed.
keypoint: My daughter fainted when they moved her

text: See, here, she never – I don’t know if they knew or what, but I blame them for the blood clot she got, taking her out of bed.
keypoint: I blame them for her fatal blood clot

text: So, when she was walking around to come home after ten days, I was waiting for the call from the hospital. I didn’t have a phone then. The lady from the store who had a phone called me, “Mrs. Costa,” at aquarter to five at night.
keypoint: I awaited her discharge without a phone

text: “Mrs. Costa, they just called you from the hospital. Go Pick Marie up. She’s discharged.”
keypoint: I was called to pick her up from the hospital

text: I had all the clothes laid out on the table. And Rita was – I was cooking, I said, “Rita, finish the cooking.” Daddy will be home soon.”
keypoint: I prepared for her return with coffee and cake

text: He was working down in the yard. I said, “And put a big pot of coffee on,” because she had been wishing for coffee. And you know, every morning, that first cup of coffee, I offered it to her. When I get up in the morning, the first cup is hers.
keypoint: I still offer her the first cup of coffee

text: Since she’s gone, I never forget that. So I said, “Put a pot of coffee on, and send for some cake from the bakery.” I’m going to get Marie; they called me.”
keypoint: I was excited to bring Marie home

text: “All right, mother, go ahead,” she said, “I’ll finish up.” And I went myself. You know, I had the coat on my arm. She was operated on in March – No, April! So that was the thirtieth.
keypoint: I went to the hospital with her clothes

text: She was operated – ten days before, so that would be the twentieth. The twentieth of April, right? It was kind of chilly. Oh, and I had everything in a bag, and I had the coat on my arm and her dress hanging on my arm.
keypoint: It was chilly when I went to get her

text: She saw me from the windows, from Wolf Street. She said, “My mother’s just coming.” She was with the girls, saying goodbye to everyone – you know how it is.
keypoint: Marie was saying goodbye to friends

text: They told me on the phone, it would be ten dollars more for her board. And to make sure I brought her girdle to put on. I said, “All right, I’ll be right over.” And I went.
keypoint: I was told to bring extra money and her girdle

text: But when I got there, the nurse said to me, “Sit down, Mrs. Costa, sit here for a while.” So I sat down, and I was praying for another lady in the hospital that had an operation for her gall bladder. She lived near my sister, and she had ten children. They had said she was in very bad shape.
keypoint: I prayed for another patient while waiting

text: I prayed, “Oh dear God, don’t take that mother away from her children.” I was praying for her, you know. Then a little nurse’s aide went to the closet and got some blankets. I started getting the chills,
keypoint: I felt chills and prayed for the sick mother

text: and I was thinking about it, when the aide said to the nurse, “Oh, she’s going into a cold sweat now.” The nurse hung up the phone and came to me. She said, “Mrs. Costa, has your daughter ever had a fainting spell?” “Oh my God!” I said, “Don’t tell me you’re running for my daughter!”
keypoint: I panicked when they mentioned my daughter

text: “Yes,” she said, “come on in.” So, I went into the room. And my daughter was on the bed with her bedroom slippers and her housecoat on. And the beads of sweat – honest to God, not to exaggerate, they were that big.
keypoint: Marie was sweating profusely on the bed

text: It came – just poured from her – I said, “What did you do, kill my daughter? You killed her! You killed her!” That’s what I kept yelling.
keypoint: I accused them of killing my daughter

text: And the doctor rushed in, see, they were trying to get the doctor, you know. She was a lady doctor. Dr. Schwartz actually did the operation, but she was his assistant, Dr. Montique.
keypoint: The doctors couldn't explain what happened

text: She was a lady doctor. So, she came in and she said – I said, “You killed my daughter – what did you do to her?” She said, “We don’t know what happened, Mrs. Costa.”
keypoint: I was distraught and demanded answers

text: She took me away from the bed. The nurse said to me, “Talk to her.” I said, “Talk to her? My daughter’s dying, what am I supposed to tell her?” And I was screaming.
keypoint: I was hysterical as Marie was dying

text: My hair was all pulled out. I went hysterical, you know what I mean? She was only eighteen years old. Beautiful girl, you can see from her picture.
keypoint: I went into shock over my young daughter's death

text: And just as I turned my back, my daughter passed away. She was getting ready to go home. I had the clothes and everything ready. My husband was waiting for her.
keypoint: Marie passed away just before going home

text: He came home, went upstairs to shave and wash, then sat on the step, waiting. “When is the mother coming?” The hospital kept calling. The people in the office didn’t know what had happened yet.
keypoint: My husband was unaware, waiting for her

text: They kept calling the store, trying to reach us. They asked, “When is the mother coming to pick up Marie? She’s discharged.” And Rita said “That’s strange, the mother went to the hospital. She should be there.”
keypoint: The hospital kept calling, unaware of her death

text: So they came back to the hospital to look for us. Rita said, “Gee, that’s strange,” she said, “Mother must’ve gotten really worked up about Marie.” You know, I’ve always had a bad heart.
keypoint: Rita worried about my reaction to Marie's discharge

text: “Mother must’ve gotten so upset about Marie, she probably made herself sick,” Rita thought. So she came over with my son-in-law, in the car. And I was in the main hallway, at the office. I was all pulled apart.
keypoint: Rita found me distraught at the hospital

text: One doctor wanted to give me a shot. I said, “Get out of here, I’ll kick you,” I said. “You killed my daughter, now you want to kill me?”
keypoint: I refused medical help, blaming them for her death

text: Another nurse came over. See, they all knew me. I had three operations in no time, not even a year. And I knew all the nurses.
keypoint: I knew the nurses from my own operations

text: “Mrs. Costa, please, take –” “Get out!” I said, “Don’t you dare come near me.” I was so hysterical. I was banging my head against the wall and everything.
keypoint: I was hysterical and refused their comfort

text: They had to grab me. Then they brought me to the office, see. When Rita came in and saw me like that, she asked, “Mother, what happened?” I said, “We lost Marie.
keypoint: Rita collapsed upon hearing of Marie's death

text: Marie died.” Well, that’s this one. This is a picture of Rita. She went down like lightning. Dropped to the floor, and that’s a marble floor.
keypoint: Rita suffered a leg injury from the shock

text: She went down like lightning. And the back of her leg, it felt just like a pole. Hard like a pole, the back of her leg. And that girl is suffering.
keypoint: Rita's leg pain persists decades later

text: Thirty – no, twenty-eight years since her sister died? When she gets that pain, it’s like she has phlebitis from it. She suffers – seven, eight, nine weeks at a time. She can’t walk, she goes through such pain since then.
keypoint: Rita's pain is a constant reminder of Marie

text: And how did they figure how Marie died? The girl who was walking with Marie, told the doctor that Marie was saying goodbye to Arlene. And all Marie said to that girl was, “Oh, I’ve got a pain in my leg and I can’t see.”
keypoint: Marie's friend described her sudden collapse

text: And then Marie collapsed. Later, they said it was a blood clot.
keypoint: Marie died from a blood clot

text: I said, “Don’t you dare touch my daughter. I’ll burn this hospital down! I don’t care who’s in it.” I said, “Don’t you dare touch my daughter.
keypoint: I threatened the hospital staff in my grief

text: You want to find out what she died from.” But if you touch my daughter, I’ll kill you.” I wouldn’t let them touch her.
keypoint: I refused an autopsy for Marie

text: So when I got home – they took me home. I was screaming in the car. I couldn’t get out, you know, I couldn’t – I was screaming!
keypoint: I was inconsolable on the way home

text: Everybody came out, coming out of their doors because they could hear the screams. My husband was sitting on the step. He asked, “What’s the matter? What happened to you?” Well, my hair was all pulled, and my face – I was a mess.
keypoint: My husband was shocked by the news

text: I didn’t know what I had done to myself. I said, “Mike, we lost Marie. Marie died.” It was just a shock. My husband had a heart attack. Yes, he had a heart attack.
keypoint: The news caused my husband a heart attack

text: Then my son, Michael, yeah. That night. Right there, my Michael came, and my Michael collapsed. He had a heart attack too, no kidding.
keypoint: My son also had a heart attack from the shock

text: It was all – my two sisters were here, waiting until about half-past four. They waited because they knew she was coming home that day, waiting for the call. My younger sister had brought an orange for Marie, and I had never seen an orange like it. It was a big orange, like that. She said, “Mary, look, when they call you, when you pick Marie up, let us know, and we’ll come over.”
keypoint: My family was waiting for Marie's return

text: I said, “All right.” So, I got home and called everybody, told them what happened. I called my brother-in-law. He was an undertaker.
keypoint: I informed everyone of Marie's death

text: My sister’s husband – he’s passed away now too. God rest his soul. Maybe you know him... So they were waiting for my call, you know, but instead, I sent my son James, he was little then.
keypoint: I sent my son to tell the family

text: I said, “Go tell Aunt Millie and Aunt Jenny.” They had cleaned the pavement, and done the cement work, and they were cleaning the pavement. They said, “Here comes little Jamie,” and now they said,
keypoint: My sisters were cleaning, expecting good news

text: “Maybe he’s come to tell us Marie’s home.” But when he got there, the poor kid’s eyes were all red. They said, “James, what’s the matter, honey? Why are you crying?”
keypoint: My son delivered the tragic news

text: “Aunt Jenny, Aunt Millie, Marie died,” he said. Well, my sisters and my mother, you know, they were all alive. It was a shock to everybody. That was a shock that –
keypoint: The death shocked the entire family

text: The neighborhood – Annie at the store always says, “Mrs. Costa,” every time I go in there, she reminds me, “I just picture Marie standing at that step, looking over here.” She used to stand at that step. She was a real quiet girl, pleasant, didn’t talk much, but she was so good, I can’t even tell you. That’s all. So that’s what happened.
keypoint: Marie's memory is still vivid in the neighborhood
